channel.title: Comments on: Don’t take my word for it

item.title: By: jerome
item.dc:creator: jerome
item.description:
No I didn't try to pitch it that way. It was done after the fact. My main goal was to inspire administrations to use such tools and I can't say I have been that successful in that respect.
The pattern I see is that media would launch or propagate an assertion which attacks the current policies. Sometimes this is backed by a huge dataset and they can use datavis to make their point (Washington post has run a few such stories). But this is not always the case. For instance, media can simply cite a politician that makes an outlandish claim.
With that in mind administration is just a sitting duck. They are not equipped to face such claims. However, if visualization is done "preemptively" to show that the policy choice that they make coincide with public interest, then such accusations can be defused. Other media, for instance, could easily point a contradiction.
So, I'm more interested in using visualizations to defend than to attack :)
I have shown this vis to various senior officials who all liked it but didn't think they could afford going in that direction in this economic context. We'll eventually get there because vis can have an enormous ROI.
and if you read this and you are in a position to commission political visualizations do get in touch! I'll be happy to advise.
